According to TCM, a person is healthy when harmony exists between these two forces;
illness, on the other hand, results from a breakdown in the equilibrium of yin and yang.
The Chinese healer may prescribe a brew prepared with one (or some combination) of thousands of medicinal plants or dried animal parts (e.
The patient may be treated with acupuncture or acupressure, moxibustion (moxa treatment), or cupping (in which hot glass cups are placed on the patient to draw blood to the skin).
This is especially true of acupuncture, tai chi, cupping, and moxibustion.
traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), system of medicine at least 23 centuries old that aims to prevent or heal disease by maintaining or restoring yinyang balance.
TCM has a significant cultural significa: In essence, traditional Chinese healers seek to restore a dynamic balance between two complementary forces, yin (passive) and yang (active), which pervade the human body as they do the universe as a whole.
Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) is a medical science and cultural heritage empirically applied and reserved by Chinese people for thousands of years.

TCM acupuncture and moxibustion have been recognized as important parts of the intangible heritage of mankind by UNESCO [12] and the Chinese medical classics Huangdi Neijing (Inner Canon of the Yellow Emperor) [13] and Bencao Gangmu (Compendium of Materia Medica) [14] have been included in the UNESCO Memory of the World.
TCM is a practical medicine built on exp: The basic structure of traditional Chinese medicine is composed of three parts: one consistent with modern medicine, one involuntarily beyond modern medicine, and one that needs to be further evaluated.

The part that is consistent with modern medicine includes consensus on several theories and concepts of traditional Chinese medicine, and usage of several treatments and prescriptions of traditional Chinese medicine including commonly used Chinese herbs.

The part that is involuntarily beyond modern medicine contains several advanced theories and important concepts of traditional Chinese medicine, relatively advanced treatments, formula and modern prescriptions, leading herbs, acupuncture treatment and acupuncture anesthesia of traditional Chinese medicine that affect modern medicine and incorporates massage treatment that has been gradually acknowledged by modern therapy.
TCM has a holistic view of the human bod: TCM holistic concept includes integrity of the body and its relationship with the outer world.
TCM treatment focuses on the overall disharmony of the body rather than specific organ or body region.

Traditional Chinese Medicine, still a major component of the health care system in China, holds a strong holistic perspective, taking human, human-nature relations and human health and illness from a holistic perspective, regarding human being as a whole, and even take human being as an integrate part of the nature, which is in sharp contrast with biological reductionism in biomedicine-dominated western medicine.
TCM practitioners use the method of \u20: Syndrome differentiation is a commonly used methodology and practice in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) guiding the diagnosis and treatment of diseases including heart failure (HF).
TCM diagnosis relies on the examination: Despite some limitations, tongue, pulse, and electrophysiological diagnosis devices have been reported as a useful tool while establishing a person’s functional status.
Traditionally, tongue and pulse diagnosis and the functional evaluation of action points by pressure sensitivity and physical examination may be regarded as essential diagnostic tools.
An acupuncturist will feel the pulse at various positions on your wrists, each corresponding to different organ systems and energy channels.

Both pulse and tongue diagnosis provide your acupuncturist with a holistic view of your body's state, guiding them in tailoring an acupuncture and holistic treatment plan that addresses your unique needs.
Through this practice, they gather information about the quality, strength, and rhythm of your pulse, assessing factors like rate, depth, and width.
In TCM, the tongue is considered a reflection of internal organ health and energy flow.
Tongue diagnosis involves closely observing the color, shape, coating, and moisture of your tongue.
TCM treatment aims to egulate the qi flo: These practices include Chinese herbal medicine and dietetics, acupuncture and moxibustion, and other non-medication therapies such as Chinese bodywork or manual therapy, known as “Tuina”, and traditional biofeedback exercises, known as “Qigong” and “Taijiquan”.
When Qi becomes blocked or unbalanced, TCM treatments aim to restore the balance and flow.
Acupuncture is the most well-known Traditional Chinese Medicine technique, where practitioners use needles to stimulate specific points on the body.
TCM treatments usually focus on promoting and maintaining the flow of Qi.
Balancing yin and yang is the goal of any TCM treatment.
Chinese medicine practitioners use a variety of methods including acupuncture, herbal medicines, acupressure, breathing techniques, and tai chi to help people improve their overall well-being.
The goal of TCM is to restore harmony within an individual and balance the forces of yin and yang, which are components of qi.
Western medicine treatment aims to elimi: Western medicine prescribes specific drugs for a disease.
Western medicine forms the basis of most modern healthcare systems in the world.
Western medicine uses a systemic approach, utilizing symptoms and separate organ systems to determine treatments.

Western or traditional medicine typically encompasses a system in which medical and healthcare professionals such as doctors, nurses, therapists and pharmacists manage and treat disease using conventional evidence-based practices such as drugs, surgery, lifestyle changes or treatment protocols.
Western medicine focuses on scientifically proven methods for diagnosing and treating illnesses.
Western medicine refers to a system where medical professionals utilize medical treatments to treat symptoms of diseases.
TCM prevention focuses on enhancing the: Yang sheng refers to a set of lifestyle practices that promote longevity and good health.
It focuses on maintaining jing (life force), qi (vital energy) and shen (“spirit” or mental health).
This is what self healing and yang sheng is all about.
Self healing is a primary concept in Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), which focuses on both disease prevention and treatment.
Modern self healing practices such as acupressure, breathing exercises (Qigong), and a mindful diet have their roots in yang sheng.
One method to promote self-healing and to nourish jing, qi and shen is through consuming the right nutrients.
Yang sheng may date back to ancient China, but its underlying concept of a holistic lifestyle is increasingly prevalent in modern health practices.
